_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Spplicable building, electrical and plumbing codes.  This facility complies with the Iowa Fertilizer Law
_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: We utilize those portions of these codes which are deemed applicable by the jurisdictional authority
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vandalism/theft (methamphetamine) provisions have been made to install a protective barrier around the plant perimeter to reduce the potential of vehicular damage
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: flow limiters (what the trade calls excess flow valves) breakaway couplers have been installed at the risers and a remote emergency shutoff valve at the storage tank
_prev_prog_2.MD_OtherType: regular plant inspection/routine preventative maintenance and repair
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: pumps, pump seals, pipes, plumbing and electrical equipment, safety equipment.  The breakaway couplers, relief valves, and hoses are also inspected and replaced as necessary

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
HE ANHYDROUS AMMONIA STORAGE/DISTRIBUTION PLANT AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED AT VILLISCA ELEVATOR INC., VILLISCA, IOWA:

This facility is a bulk anhydrous ammonia storage and distribution plant.  The anhydrous ammonia that is stored at this facility is distributed to agricultural crop producers in the surrounding area who utilize the anhydrous ammonia for crop nutrient purposes.

The system consists of one (1) 18,000 gallon storage tank with associated puping, valves, liquid pumps and other miscellaneous equipment.  From time-to-time throughout the year, as many as twenty-five (25) 1,000 gallon and four (4) 1,450 gallon portable nurse tanks may be present at this site.  

THE WORST-CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO:

The worst case scenario is the failure of the largest storage tank when filled to capacity, resulting in the release of the total volume of contents in a gaseous form.  According to EPA's RMP Comp Program (Version 1.06) the distance to the endpoint is 3.3 miles.

The alternative release scenario involves th etransport delivery vehicle pulling away from the intake lines into the storage plant without disconnecting the transfer hoses.  The resulting release, according to EPA's RMP Comp Program has a distance to endpoint of 0.1 miles.  

The system is protected from major releases by a series of valves and breakaway couplers, all designed to stop the contents flow in th eevent of a break.  When not in use, the storage tank valves are locked.

Since this facility is located in relatively close proximity to the town of Villisca, Iowa, provisions have been designed to notify all affetced persons.  An evacuation plan is in place.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:

This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule and all applicable State and local codes and regulations.  The anhydrous ammonia system is designed, installed and maintained in accordance with ANSI Standard K-61.1-1989 with am

endments and State Law.

In addition, the company has specific operating procedures in place intended to minimize the potential for an accidental and potentially catastrophic release of anhydrous ammonia.  Finally, Villisca Elevator, Inc. has extended to the Villisca Volunteer Fire Department the opportunity to visit our anhydrous ammonia plant, to participate in mock emergency simulation training, and to avail themselves of specific anhydrous ammonia health hazard information provided by the company.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

Villisca Elevator Inc, Villisca, Iowa has never had an accident involving anhydrous ammonia that caused death, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations or shelterings in place.

THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN:

In the event of an emergency involving our anhydrous ammonia system, it is the policy of Villisa Elevator Inc. to immediately notify the Villisca Volunteer Fire Department and the LEPC to request that they respond to the emergency.  In the unlikely event that the Villisca fire department is unable to adequately respond to an emergency at our Villisca location, alternative arrangements for emergency response have been made and discussed with the Villisca Fire Department and the LEPC.  Members of the fire department and the LEPC have inspected our anhydrous ammonia plant.  In addition, copies of photographs taken of our plant have been provided for reference to both entities.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

The plan is to minimize those hazards to human health and to the environment that are associated with accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. Employees working at the bulk storage plant make routine observations prior to and during transfer operations of the anhydrous ammonia from the storage vessel(s) to nurse tanks. In so doing, they are able to detect problems before they arise. This routine inspection identifies any portion of the system which may be under stress or about to fail. Repairs can be made before t

hey become problematic. Employees are annually trained to recognize the hazards associated with storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia. In addition to annual training for employees who have been on the job for a number of years, the company conducts training for new hires. This training includes classroom instruction, on-site training at the plant, and follow-up observation to determine their individual comprehension and understanding of the new hire. Finally, the company routinely invites  local fire department personnel to visit the site. In the event that the local fire department requests assistance in training its employees on anhydrous ammonia, the company cooperates fully in their endeavors.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE AT FARMERS COOPERATIVE COMPANY, VALLISCA, IOWA:

This facility complies with ANSI Standard K-61.1-1989 requirements with amendments for Anhydrous Ammonia storage.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal, State and local regulations.  If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to immediately notify the Vallisca Volunteer Fire Department via 911 call, and request that it respond to the emergency.  Incidental to the notification of the fire department, a call to the local LEPC will be made.

While we have planned for an emergency, it is acknowledged that a real emergency will be unexpected and may very well be much different and cannot be ensured to duplicate what may have been planned.  In reality, the situation that develops may not happen in the manner in which it has been planned.  In that event, what may have been planned will serve only as a guideline to follow.

The Emergency Action Plan for this facility describes certain procedures that are intended to minimize the hazards associated with human health and the environment from fires, explosions, the sudden and unexpected release of chemicals (ie anhydrous ammonia) tornadoes, bomb threats or other accidents or acts of God which might occur on our premises.  

The primary emergency coordinator for the Vallisca, Iowa location is Daivd Lindburg, Manager.  His work and 24 hour emergency response telephone numbers are provided in the Registration Section of this document.  In addition, the following individuals (with associated telephone numbers) are to be contacted in order:
